docs.lead_paragraph: The Seduction of Hillary Rodham By David Brock Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: The Free Press. $26. If conflict lies at the heart of great drama, then surely Hillary Rodham Clinton is one of the great characters of our age. She is the embodiment of conflicts that all but define our time: marriage versus career; motherhood versus profession; truth versus expedience; power versus accountability; image versus reality. In her fateful decision to tether her fortunes to William Jefferson Clinton can be seen the origins of a plot that, as it accelerates into and beyond Nov. 5, has all the hallmarks of triumph and tragedy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of people are expected to become trapped in places that are extremely vulnerable to environmental change in the course of this century, according to a British government study released on Thursday.
docs.abstract: Environmental change is just as likely to trap people as it is to make them migrate - or it can cause them to flee to even more vulnerable areas, a British government study warns.

headline.main: Millions Will Be Trapped Amid Climate Change, Study Warns

docs.lead_paragraph: South Boston's dingy waterfront, known mainly for its convention center, is readying for this fall's most hotly anticipated new building: the 65,000-square-foot Institute of Contemporary Art (100 Northern Avenue; www.icaboston.org), designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro. The first new art museum in the city in almost 100 years, it will feature a glass-walled top floor that swoops out above the water, a digital-media room suspended from a gallery for horizonless views and nary a support beam in sight. Add a Wolfgang Puck cafe and a theater, and it's no wonder city planners believe the ICA can help revitalize the district. Two other recent additions: the Westin Boston Waterfront hotel (425 Summer Street; 800-937-8461; www.westin.com; doubles from $359) and L.T.K. (Legal Test Kitchen), Legal Sea Foods' high-tech -- digital menus and iPod docks at tables -- Asian-fusion outpost (225 Northern Avenue; 617-330-7430; entrees $9-$24). HILLARY GERONEMUS
